Parameters: int: a valid index in the current Cursor or -1 to use the default conversion mechanism
setStringConversionColumn(int).Description: Defines the index of the column in the Cursor used to get a String representation of that Cursor. The column is used to convert the Cursor to a String only when the current CursorToStringConverter is null.

Returns: null if the converter does not exist or an instance of @B_android#widget#SimpleCursorAdapter#CursorToStringConverter_E@
getCursorToStringConverter().Description: Returns the converter used to convert the filtering Cursor into a String.

Returns: a valid index in the current Cursor or -1
getStringConversionColumn().Description: Return the index of the column used to get a String representation of the Cursor.

Returns: a ViewBinder or null if the binder does not exist
getViewBinder().Description: Returns the @B_android#support#v4#widget#SimpleCursorAdapter#ViewBinder_E@ used to bind data to views.

Returns: a non-null CharSequence representing the cursor
Parameters: Cursor: the Cursor to convert to a CharSequence
convertToString(android.database.Cursor).Description: Returns a CharSequence representation of the specified Cursor as defined by the current CursorToStringConverter. If no CursorToStringConverter has been set, the String conversion column is used instead. If the conversion column is -1, the returned String is empty if the cursor is null or Cursor.toString().

Returns: Returns the previously set Cursor, or null if there was not one. If the given new Cursor is the same instance is the previously set Cursor, null is also returned.
Parameters: Cursor: The new cursor to be used.
swapCursor(android.database.Cursor).Description: Swap in a new Cursor, returning the old Cursor. Unlike @B_android#support#v4#widget#CursorAdapter#changeCursor_E@, the returned old Cursor is not closed.

ClassDesc: Static library support version of the framework's https:##developer#android#com@B_android#widget#SimpleCursorAdapter_E@. Used to write apps that run on platforms prior to Android 3.0. When running on Android 3.0 or above, this implementation is still used; it does not try to switch to the framework's implementation. See the framework SDK documentation for a class overview.
